PROGRAM PREPARATORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
1.  A program preparatory technical assistance (PPTA) is required to develop a program to 
be financed by the Asian Development Bank (ADB).1 The PPTA will conduct technical, financial, 
economic, institutional, sector policy, legal, regulatory, poverty, social, gender and safeguard 
assessments of the project and the proposed subproject investments in each city. An integrated 
urban and environment planning development program drawing on outputs of the project will be 
prepared that will lead to the design of the component on increased competencies.

D.  Consulting Services 
4.  The PPTA will require 62 person-months (pm) of international and 73 pm of national 
consulting services, engaged through a firm; and 19 pm of international and 35 pm of national 
consulting services, engaged individually. ADB will engage the consultants in accordance with 
ADB’s Guidelines on Use of Consultants (2013, as amended from time to time). The quality-and 
cost-based selection method will be used with quality-cost ratio of 90:10. National consultants 
will be hired at post-PPTA to provide support to the start-up of the loan project.

5.  The outline terms of reference for the PPTA consultants are described in paras 6 to 13.  
 
6.  Sector  and  subsector  analysis. The  consultants  will  review  and  analyze  relevant 
national  and  local  plans,  strategies  and  policies  on  urban  development,  and  environment 
management particularly on disaster risk management (DRM) and climate change adaptation. 
 
7.  Technical aspects. For each city the consultants will assess subsector development 
plans and available decision making tools to support the Green City Action Plan, technical 
appraisal of proposed subprojects (including climate-proofing design features), and prepare 
plans and guidelines for operation and maintenance of infrastructure, fiduciary (procurement, 
financial and anticorruption) systems, and project administration.

14  Appendix 4         
8.  Economic analysis. The consultants will conduct socioeconomic baseline surveys and 
development  needs  assessment  through  strengths,  weaknesses,  opportunities,  and  threats 
analysis, economic benefit appraisal of subprojects, and cost-benefit analysis of integrated 
urban and environment planning. 
 
9.  Fiduciary systems assessment. The consultants will assess the program’s fiduciary 
systems’ ability to manage fiduciary risks and provide reasonable assurance for the appropriate 
use  of  program  funds.  The  overall  output  will  be  a  fiduciary  systems  assessment  which 
assesses financial management, procurement and corruption risks and recommend mitigating 
measures, including capacity-development activities.  
 
10.  Safeguards assessment (Environment, Involuntary Resettlement, and Indigenous 
Peoples) and climate change and disaster risk management. The consultants will assess 
gaps of national laws and regulations vis-a-vis the ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009). A 
program safeguard system assessment will be prepared, along with a program action plan. The 
consultants will conduct environmental screening, review climate change and natural disaster 
risks, and propose climate and disaster resilient measures to be addressed in the engineering 
designs. The safeguard category of the program will be confirmed.  
 
11.  Institutional analysis and capacity strengthening. The consultants will assess the 
institutional, regulatory, and human resource requirements for project implementation and for 
urban planning, environment, climate and disaster risk management, and service delivery.  
 
12.  Social, poverty, and gender analyses. The consultants will prepare poverty and social 
analysis using participatory methods in accordance with ADB’s Handbook on Social Analysis 
(2007) and ADB’s Handbook for Incorporation of Social Dimensions in Projects (1994) to assess 
the type and significance of the project impacts on the poor, women and any other vulnerable 
groups.  The  consultant’s  outputs  will  consist  of  a  gender  action  plan,  participation  plan 
(including participation in disaster risk management), stakeholder communication, and summary 
poverty reduction and social strategy.     
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
13.  The Ministry of Planning and Investment will be the coordinating ministry. The provincial 
people’s  committees  of  Ha Giang, Thua Thien  Hue,  and  Vinh  Phuc  will  be  the  executing 
agencies. The city people's committees (CPCs) of Ha Giang, Hue, and Vinh Yen will be the 
implementing agencies, with the CPC of Hue as lead. The government will provide qualified 
counterpart staff, office, logistics, and necessary data and reports.
